en: Language and Culture interviews from East Texas

body.value:
This is [INTERVIEWER]. Today is June 25, and I'm here in Beaumont, Texas for an interview with one
of our community members. Before we begin, I'd like to get verbal consent for the form that we went
over. Can you please say I consent to being interviewed and audio recorded for this study?
I've been... um, could give you my consent for this audio and recording.
To get started, can you tell me about how you came to live in this community?

Well, I was born in this community. And with my father and my mother. When I, you know, know that I
was in this community and never left this community.

Can you tell me a bit more about this community? How would you describe it to someone who doesn't
live here?

Well, from my experience, and being here this long, it's a good community in certain areas. And why I
mean in certain areas, and certain times of the years that we're in... everybody got along in this
community when, you know, when I was born. And my teenage, teenage years was great. As I look
now, where we at, I was born in 1964. 19, 20 [reffering to 2019 and 2020], when everything with 1920,
to 19... um, um... I mean... let me change that. 19 [reffering to 2019], um, when COVID hit. Everything
started changing around. From everyone getting sick, you see more depression, you know in people.
More killing. I never thought I would see my town turn into a disaster due to COVID. Where everybody
was locked in and people just thought, you know, getting out of control. Other than that, the crime has
never been... that I I was aware of and living here where I was scared to go places. Or just to approach
a young child and to correct them. You know, right now you got kids that you don't even know their
parents anymore. Where they're coming from. Because it's not just the kids, it's parents too. That bad
depression hit us as, I would say mind wise. You know, mental state. And you see it every day. And this
is when everything started changing around 2019. Harvey [reffering to Hurrican Harvey], didn't bother
us as much. We got hit with Harvey, but everybody made a comeback. But when COVID hit, it just took
a lot away from the family. You know, just totally Beaumont, Beaumont period. It took a lot away from
everybody. Yes.
How do you think this community has changed throughout your time living here?

A lot. Had changed a lot. You know, from gas prices, from everything in place went up. Everything went
up. Food, everything, everything. You know, the cost of living never changed, but everything in prices
wise. And this is why I think family is struggling with hardmental, you know, stage right now. Affording to
keep the rent. Affording to keep food on the table. You know, all the jobs, that has been lost due- from
restaurants. And you know, it's- it's just not a community like can be brought back at this time. If you
don't get the job, if you don't get what these family have, what they need, and they don't have what they
need. That's why you have so much crime.
What would you say are the strengths of this community?
Prayers. Prayer. That's the strength we have right now. Nothing but prayers.
What would you say are some of the weaknesses of this community?

The weakness of this community... just being lost. You know. Don't have enough, um. I would say an of
um... people that... I would speak up as a voice, um, first responders. You know, being first responders,
it's not just first responder. Responders when someone gets hurt in the hospital. But we are not trained
for the medical problems that we're having. And for seeing in the homeless in this community now.
Seeing people walking around here. The drug infested. You know, due to the mental state, we do not
have enough mental institute around here to take care of it.
Can you tell me about the roles and relationships you have in this community?

I play a lot of roles. You know, I'm a Participant. I'm a provider, take carer. I'm a respectable person in this
community. Always has been, and this is what hurts me. To see I can't do anything at this point. It's got
to take from the higher up to recognize what's going on to give us the source that we also need to
provide to bring this community back.
What do you do for work?

Everything. I try to do everything and fit in places where maybe I shouldn't be. But to see that
everybody is working together as a group. Or everybody, we're working together as a group, and
making my work where everybody feel like they have a part of a family here. So it's just like, if you need
something, and if I have it, I'm willing to help you with it. Try to direct you to the right source that who
can help you.
How do you think your connections in this community influence your work as a therapist technician?

A lot, because I learn from the therapist. And the ther-, you know, assistant therapy. So it's like, hands
on, eyes on. And you can learn a lot from them. You know, just watching and listening.
Now, I'd like to talk more about your work. Could you tell me about how you got into this role?

Well, I got into this role. I was blessed with this role through the good Lord. I was taking care of my
father, and what happened was, they told me, I couldn't take care of him no more after he got sick. And
I refused to give him up. And what happened was, when I refused to give him up, I still took him home
with me. I didn't want to see him in a nursing home. But I had applied for the medical position. And I will
sitting, and my dad was having surgery, getting ready to go to surgery because he had a, a brain bleed.
And I was sitting there and I told- because I was a manager downtown at Goodwill. I have license as a
beautician. And I spoke to the Lord. And I say, Lord, I'm not going to give my dad up to go back and
work and do those positions that I already had. Because I dropped all to take care of my dad. And I
said, Lord, you're gonna have to fix it. And this voice came, it's like, "I will fix it". And I'm listening. And I
got a phone call from [NAME OF HOSPITAL IN COMMUNITY]. And I said, I see what you saying, God.
I'm gonna have to give him up, but you've given me more people to go take care of that needs me. And
you the only one to fix it because it's like, what I wanted to do for my dad, I want to do it for anybody
else. But I still brought him home, now. Okay, until I wasn't able. I wasn't a registered nurse to give him
his medicine that he was going to be needing with injection. And I cried all the way to bring it into the
nurse. But I was able to visit him every day. I made sure I was able to visit him every day where I put
him. And he had the best care when I put him into nursing home. [DOOR CLOSES] Mhm.
How long have you been working here?

25 years. Also not in the outpatient. I started in inpatient, in the hospital. And then I transfer over to the
outpatient because I had young kids and allowed me to even adjust my schedule. I had two sons. The
adjust- allow me to adjust my schedule, where I was able to be there in the evening on time to pick
them up from school. So that's why I transfer to outpatient the time. And they had opening.
What does a typical workday look like for you?

Everyday is busy. Everyday is busy. A typical work places making sure everyone is safe. Everyone is
taken care of. I does what I, I do, um water, um, aquatic class. And I do three classes a day. And I have
over 15 to 20 ladies in the pool. So my responsibility 'cause the floor stays wet, to make sure they're
safe. I'm safe. And make sure I know each and every last one of them by their name when I speak to
them.
What does it mean to be a therapist technician in this community?

It means a lot. It means a lot. Because one day I might need a therapis. And just to know the things that
I seen my therapist do. To know that one day I'm gonna be that age or one day on the need a good
therapist. And knowing that I have worked around good service that have you know, just teaching me a
lot about bones, this back. People from stroke. Just knowing that what I'm getting out of it. Being a
good technician. That's what it is. Mhm.
What aspects of your job bring you the most joy or satisfication?

Seeing someone that came in, they couldn't walk. And watching my therapist then get them back on
their feet to live a normal back to their independent life.
What are the biggest challenges you face in your work?

Well, there's no challenges that I face. Because even if I can't do it, I'm going to try to do it. You know,
before I give up,. So that's the challenge. Trying to do it and then just say, "No, I can't do it." You know?

Now let's talk more about your experiences as a resident of this community. For the first set of
questions, I'll read a statement to you. And I'd like you to indicate the extent of your agreement with
each one. I'll have you give your answer on a scale to one to four. One is completely disagree. Two is
somewhat disagree. Three is somewhat agree, and four is completely agree. If you'd like to comment
on any of these statements, please feel free to. The first phrase is "I consider myself to be an
American." Would you say that you: one- completely disagree, two- somewhat disagree, three-
somewhat agree, or four- completely agree?
Using the same scale, how would you rate the following statement? "I consider myself to be a Texan."
I strongly believe I'm a Texan

Which of the following three statements do you agree with most strongly? I am American first and
Texan second. I am a Texan first and American second. Or being Texan and American are equally
important to me.

Equally important to me. That one right there. Being a Texan and an American is equally important to
me. I can, you know, it doesn't matter to me. And why I say that is because I am American. But all
above, I don't look at if I'm a Texan. If I'm over here, I'm over there. My thing is, I'm the person who I am
and I will treat you as you treat me.

Yes. The next phase is, "To be a true Texan, you must know how to speak English." What would you
rate this one using the same scale we started with?

I disagree. I totally disagree. To be a Texan, you don't have to speak English. I totally disagree with
that.
How about, "To be a true Texan, you must know how to speak Spanish."

The next phrase is, "In my community, you can do everything you want and get everything you need,
even when you don't speak English."
Um, completely agree or somewhat agree?

I... on that, saying that, it's just like English. Okay, and it's just like if you speak Spanish or another
religion. It's not that it's hard for you to get anything. It's how you look at it. Because everyone should
be treated equally. And that's the way I'm answering that. It's not about how I speak. Everyone should
be treated equally. And that's the way I treat everyone. It doesn't matter. Even if I go in the back of the
parking lot, and I see someone's is Hispanic, Filipino or whatever. If they need help, or trying to find
something, they don't have to speak. They hand me their phone, and I can give them the direction. So
you understand where I'm coming from. I'm not looking at what language you speak. I'm trying to make
sure you get where you need to be and treat it where you feel comfortable. Where you can walk up to
me if you see me no matter what color I am, no matter how I speak. I want to make sure you okay, if
you walk up to me. I will not turn my back on no one. Has been here 60 years, I was not raised that
way.

Finally, "In my community life has been pretty stable over the last 40 years. Things haven't changed
much." Completely disagree, somewhat disagree, somewhat agree or completely agree?
I disagree. A lot have change.
Strongly disagree. A lot have change.

Now I'd like to hear from you about the community itself. What are some of the things that have
changed in this community during the last few decades?

Like I say, more sickness. More killing. More unhappy homes, kids and family. More parents not at
home. Broken community. It's a broken community. And when you have a broken community, you don't
know- it's more angry people that treat good people wrong. Because it's broken. I, all the days I went, I
worked plenty jobs, and I can communicate and my co workers- it didn't matter who you were. Now it's
like, it's broken. People have no respect for each other anymore. Kids, the dressing of the community of
young people. You know, putting them somewhere, and someone house and it's not to help them. You
know, kids are having babies back to back. You know, it's, it's very broken. You know, it's very broken.
No communication. And even with the school district, I have never seen the schools just failing our kids,
due to our kids being disrespectful of a teacher. That's hard for a teacher to teach.
Overall, is this a good community to live in?

It can go back to being that. I would never give up on my community. I would never give up on the ones
that's with mental health or anythin. I would never give up on it. Every place is a good place. Just gotta
get the resources. And if we get the resources that we need back in here, you know, because you have
to look at it really. Not too many people want to be cops anymore. Not too many people want to try to
fire when it's hot outside. Not too many people want to put their lives in jeopardy because they got
families, they want to make sure they come home. So that's beautiful. So back then when a police
officer can tell you to stop, you would do that. [BACKGROUND VOICE] You know, if a police officer,
you can walk up and shake his hand, a fire department. We'd had all of these people around, and we
knew their family. Now that you have this generation that comes about, it's totally different. If you don't,
it's not from the neighborhood, or family member here that stayed here. Either they're dead, or they go
and take care of a loved one that moved out of town or another. But you don't have that age, that's still
living at my age got to see these days of good people that still around to you know. We got to start
somewhere with these family and these houses and these kids. You know, they got more, I'm gonna
put it like that. I worked all my life take care of my kids. But when you having four and five kids, and the
government handing you the money to put them in these type of houses- please you think they're
gonna be able to stop having kids? You ever think they going- they get more groceries, they get more
light bills paid anybody. So you looking at a community, you understand that what I gotta go to work
for? Why I got to go out here and work and I'm getting a fee each month? More money than me is when
you get in 14 and $1,500 in income tax for a kid and also getting government money for them. What
they're gonna work for? And if you look in the community, you got more hair, wig shops and everything.
They're not closing. Yea. They're not closing. The restaurants closing. Okay, you see what I'm saying?
So when you got that going on what that tell you? Hair, nails, and eyelashes and all of this going on
what that tell you? Yeah, that's what community at. Okay. [LAUGHTER] I'm just being honest, they
don't care about- why they're gonna go work at a restaurant? And when you can sit home and get
$1,500 for each kid each month.
What was or is the best part about being a kid or young person in this community?

We was never a- we had a garden, my parents. All our friends came over and there was respect. My
parents knew their parents. So when one kid get in trouble, you might can't come to our house for a
week. We didn't have the TV or the phone. We couldn't- we weren't allowed to use the phone. And we
weren't allowed to have a phone because we had house phone. I didn't learn my phone number until I
got old enough and I looked at my dad hard hat. That's where my mom take the number. We didn't
have access to our house phone. It was only used for emergency. If he went to work, or his job needed
to call or my mom talked to her sisters and brothers, you know, his family. And we had all friends, the
whole community knew us. They would come down help us in the garden. We had a well. We would
plant our own food, everything. And we, we stayed together as kids because now the neighborhood
where I grew up in is gone. All the houses gone. Parents then died off. Some of the kids moved away
and never came back for these parent's home. And they you know, [INAUDIBLE] they all still working. I
have a few classmates, like this weekend, I had this um retired. Kids going to college, you know. We're
the last- we seem like we're the last generation besides the parents that was- let me slow- the parents
death around my age, everyone of them kids are doing good, 60, 65 and that age. Because we all grew
up in the same neighborhood at that time. You know where your kids at, you know what they're doing.
Like with you, as a young lady, you have working parents, so they showed you more. You got parents
in your household like I did. You know, and they demand that you respect them. They demand that you
go to school. That's not for them. That was for you to get your job. And that's what was told to me. You
not going to school to give me A's and B's. This is your job. Same way I'm going my job, you better
respect that teacher. And back then you would get paddled. You wouldn't, you wouldn't- if you did
something wrong that teacher caught, you gonna get paddled at school, and you better not disrespect
that teacher. And you're gonna get a whopping when you get home. And they wouldn't just giving away
grades, you know, they made sure you, um, got it. [LAUGHTER] Tell you a lot more than what you
thought I was. [LAUGHTER] But it's okay, I gotta tell you. Like I gotta tell you. Mhm.

Do you feel that the traditional way of life in this community is going on- going away? And if not, if your
answer is yes, why do you think that's the case? And if no, what do you think keeps things the same?

Like I say, no, I don't think it's going away. I just believe in the time that was, you know, everything
change. And like I said, we got good community leaders. We got people that still help from the city, you
know, from our mayor and Mayor West and like I say, just bringing the community back. And like I said,
it's not the community that- it was, like I explained, it's when COVID hit. This is when everybody started,
you know, lockdown.Llockdown, people came in, a lot of people didn't understand lockdown. You know,
that was the thing. Our city never been in lockdown as long as the years I've been here. And there was
a mental challenge for a lot of people and young people. So you look at that, and you can't go
anywhere. Your parents telling you, "You're not going anywhere because it's a lock down." You still
can't go and just stay at home. You're not going because there's a sickness, because you got elderly
grandmothers in your house. You can't go down there and play outside still, because COVID. COVID
locked everybody because nobody wants to get sick; people start dying. So you imagine what the
parents, barely can go to start with their head at home. When you think about Spectrum or you
download any game on TV. So you imagine that. And always, games the kids was playing while some
other students still had to go to work when they was in school. That was some mother's babysitter.
Because 30 minutes the mom is coming home when the kid was getting out of school. So you imagine
that mom all day, the one that's forced like me a nurse first responder. Leaving that child at home and
didn't have a choice but to work because you first respond. You understand what I'm saying? You just
can't take off when you're a first responser. So nobody was prepared for this. Not even the kids, not
being able to see different. So you look at this. Light bill going up at home. Water bill going up at home.
Groceries. And then these kids are locked down all day. Not able to see they friends; not even to talk to
them because all kids didn't have cell phones. And then it came where okay, they decided to give them,
the year before, but- nobody had the internet when they needed the tablet when school started. So
some parents couldn't afford the internet. So the only way they was able to connect on an internet, if
somebody next door allowed them to help that. You know they cope. So you imagine them kids in that
house all day. And another one didn't they also put what is suppose day of school online

So that's why they started given out tablets, BISD, to try to catch up here with the school. You know,
the state where the schools still get the fundings and things that they needed. But that didn't happen.
Kids weren't getting up on time because they were so depressed. You know, they weren't looking at
doctor's office was close. The ones that needed they medicine. MHMR close. It was a lot of things that
shut down with COVID. So you imagine how bad psych weekend is. And when I say it's bad, it's bad.
Hospital overcrowding. So these people couldn't get they medicine. So we had to deal with it. We had
to go in patient's room. You know, that had COVID because some of them came from the - remember
the nursing home. All of this was locked down. So this is when I noticed everything has started
changing for Beaumont. Around COVID. That's when it started getting more violent, more killing. Kids
fighting they parents. You know, it just, the news went crazy. Yeah.
What is your favorite sports team?

Dallas Cowboy. And why is that? It's my favorite team because I grew up with my brother them, and
they was Dallas Cowboy. And so when you're in the household with your family, you gotta to stick
together, stay together. So ain't no one going be no Red Skin and a nobody gon--. If your dad is a Dallas
Cowboy fan, you're gonna stick and stay in the south. [LAUGHTER] That's how it came, when it came,
and the first time I watched the first football Dallas Cowboy, Rogers Staubach was the quarterback.
You don't know nothing about him [LAUGHTER]. That's when I came to know football. Roger Staubach
was the quar-. And he had throwing, he'd call them a Hail Mary. And it'd be like, one minute left on the
clock. And he'll throw it all the way down the- all the way down the field. And guess what? We win
[LAUGHTER]. We be behind, but we win. Okay? Yeah. [LAUGHTER] And the clock goes out. And
that's it. Win by one point. [LAUGHTER] And he did that about maybe, I'm telling when I was about
maybe five or six, maybe, maybe maybe six times he'd threw a Hail Mary.
Oh yeah? So how have the Dallas Cowboys been doing lately?

Well, we hadn't won in a pretty good minute. But my nephew graduated from here. And Mr. Jerry Jones
hired him when he went to, uh, uh, UT of Dallas. He became Jerry Jones private- he was doing working
for that. Uh, um, the Dallas Cowboy and Jerry Jones. Seeing him doing his, um, own thing, his, um,
tour. And when he- he didn't know that was Jerry Jones and Jerry Jones hired my nephew at the
stadium. And to work his box. And that was pretty- that was, that was the most we've ever. Now we're
official Dallas Cowboys. [LAUGHTER] Because he gave him the key to- he gave him the key to the city.
They love him. Mhm. UT of Arlington. He became an ambassador. He became the U- uh the king at
UT. And right now he's in Los Angeles. And when I tell you he's famous, a celebrity now. [LAUGHTER]
He did what he was supposed to do. And my sister work every day hard to take care of her kids to
make sure that they had what she didn't. And all of them doing good, all the two kids doing good.
Oh really? Did you have to do chores when you were younger? Or now?

I did chores when I was six. It was eight of us. So we all had a week washing dishes. I don't care how
big the pots or the pan was. With 8 of us, we was we was responsible. Our house never, ever [DOOR
SHURTS] was dirty, out of eight kids. And out of the eight kids, it's the boys, it's me and my sister. And
all together it was a three bedroom. And my dad went to work every day and our house stayed perfectly
clean. Yes, I had chores. Cooking, everything that a mom would do because I was the oldest sister,
and I had four young ones under me. I was the middle. Middle, and I was the oldest girl at the middle.
Mhm.

Really none. Because I would- I did all I, I enjoy what. You know, it really wasn't none. We had to do it.
We had to do it. We didn't have no decision to make the worst. You know which one you don't like to
do. We had to do it.
What was the chore you didn't mind so much?

Cooking. I like cooking. Just to see the smile on my brother and sister. Who they wanted to cook today?
Mom or me? So you know they picked me.

I like cooking. That's my best- I don't go out and eat at restaurants. I like to cook. I'll go, but I gotta be
invited. But other than that, I'm going home to cook. [LAUGHTER] I don't like anybody's food. I've tried,
but I like my food. [LAUGHTER] Cooking. I was taught how to cook really good.
Did you ever get caught pretending to do a chore but not really doing it?

No. We got- we had checks. [LAUGHTER] Our parents would come behind you and check. So we you
know, if that, if I did, I can't remember. Because if you didn't do it, you're not going outside and play.
You're not going with your friends. And they always check behind us to make sure we did what you're
supposed to do. And we did.
Some people think that it's hard for boys and girls to be friends, what do you think?

Easy. It was easy for me because like I said, I'm in the middle. And they had no choice. So when my
big brother wanted to go play with his friends, he had to take me with him. So they all took care of me in
the neighborhood I was raised in because they have sisters. And if my mom had to cook or do
anything, I had to go with my big brother. I started at the age of six. Like I said, because during the time
I started school, school, they say, and said that I wouldn't turn the age. I was too old to go to, um,
preschool. So I missed a year, and I started in kindergarten. So at that time, my brother had- he, he
was, uh, throwing newspapers for the Beaumont Enterprise. So he would go to, um, school, and they
would bring all the papers to the house. So the thing was, by the time he get home, he showed me how
to roll this newspaper. So when he got home, I roll out his newspaper and put them in plastic bags if it
rained it didn't. I had to put the rubber band around. And he had a banana-seat bicycle. So I would ride
on the back of it and help him throw newspapaer. [LAUGHTER] I had a good childhood life, I really did.
I enjoyed my brother and sister. Mhm.

Did you ever tell a story about another person thinking the other person was not near you, but then
turned around and saw that person was standing right next to you? Could you tell me about this? What
happened?

Never. Never. If I got something to say about you, or this is like I said what I was talking about, if I got
something to say I'll talk to you. I've never experienced nothing like that in my life. Because if I meet
you, and say something happened to me and you or something. No, I'm not going to discuss it with
nobody else. And if I don't like it I'll come pull you to the side, but I never experienced that. I never did,
never that I can recall in 60 years have I've been here.
A lot of people think of the 1990s as the golden decade of pop music. Do you agree?

It was good music. It wasn't no cursing. I agree. It wasn't no nasty talking music. Yes, I agree. It was
more relaxed. Because you can turn the radio on and ride all day long with your children in the car. My
parents can turn music on all day long, and we can ride; we all singing the same song. You can play it
in your household. Now you turn the radio on, now you don't even know what you're listening to. You
don't know what channel you going get. But when I was a kid, we all sing along when we riding in the
car. Or we played music and put our little brown Participant and the music- and the window while we cut
the grass. When we get to play baseball. [LAUGHTER] It'd be 15-20 kids in our yard. Okay, we got our
own baseball field, played baseball. And they come in and they know our place as "the bottom". They
call it "the bottom". All the kids will come to "the bottom" because they like coming down here. And then
on Saturday and Sunday that was our- after we finished, my brother and cutting the grass and
everything. We would all the kids would meet us there about three, four o'clock, and our parents sit on
the porch. And my mom would fix the sand, um, sandwich and make us some Kool Aid. And you know
we have our [?] when they watch us play baseball. And we would put out the brown Participant in the
window, and, and our parents and neighbors next door. Like I said we have a big fence. We have a
whole team on both sides. [LAUGHTER] Out field and in field. So we did our chores. We love that,
yeah. You could play, turn the radio on any station, and it was good music. You turn the radio on now, I
can't even play the radio for my grandbaby. I have to turn, every few seconds I got to turn the channel.
You know even back then you had just the musical part of the- you know the jazz or the musical part.
But now, the sounds these kids hear if you don't turn the radio off. I didn't let my kids, I mean. My son
brought the first rapping tape home. Okay, he had tell you. And you know the little square box. It's Dr.
Dre. [LAUGHTER] I'm just gonna be honest [LAUGHTER]. "Let me hearing what you hearing." Baby,
by the time I took that, I'll tell you. My momma was stumped my [?]. I stumped it right, I mean when I
took it out and then I hear what they was saying and I [STOMP]. I crushed the whole tape. A friend
gave it to him; they switched out from the tape I brought him.

Cause see because Prince, you know. I like that. But he didn't got- well rapping just first come out. I
see him bouncing. [DOOR SHUTS] [LAUGHTER] I was like, nah, something wrong. [LAUGHTER]
Something was wrong with that. You know with just the little cassette, they put on the first cassette. As,
let me tell you the day. My mama, I said don't you ever let me hear you do that kind of music. And to
think my, um, both my boys right now. They'll play like from Prince, Michael Jackson, all those old
people. I mean from every pop star they know that they don't get in the car and turn on music on I like
that with me. No, [LAUGHTER] my grandbaby there. Mm mm. But I got it on the radio station, just say
102.1 and you hear Cardi B. I know you know about Cardi B. And she come on now, I hurry up

And the Community Reinvestment Act says, "bank, you must do some things, in your community to benefit- using your banking knowledge, using your skills to help people who are low income". So we look for thing- and if you do not, if you don't score well, you can even be monetarily penalized when you're audited on this. Okay. I've lived in Texas all my life. I was born in Titus County, and when I was five, we moved to a farm near White House which is southeast of Tyler. I liked growing up in the country. When my chores were done, I'd ride my horse, climb trees or hike down to the creek to fish or swim. One time, we tied a rope to a limb of a cypress tree, and would swing out wide over the swimming hole and drop into the water. Pretending to be Tarzan swinging on a vine. In the spring, I'd fly kites, and on summer nights, we'd catch fireflies, but we call them lightning bugs. Once in a while we'd have fights with corncobs or pine cones. In the winter, we'd build a fire in the fireplace and pop popcorn and roast peanuts and pecans. I guess I was a live wire. When I was 19, I went to work in Dallas in a Firestone Tire store. I didn't like city life, and for a long time I'd go home every chance I got. Mama would always cook my favorite food: fried okra, hoppin john, that's rice and Black Eyed Peas, and pecan pie. We had lots of good times, but going home is not the same now. After daddy died, mom sold the farm and moved to Tyler. I'd rather be living on a farm right now instead of here in the city, but my wife and kids don't understand me when I gripe about city life and talk about moving to the country. My oldest child says "Daddy, that's crazy. I'd just die if I had to live on a farm" I almost cried the first time she said that. I know Texas is changing, but I try to make sure we don't lose touch with our roots. While we may live in a city, I want my kids to have a good feeling for the land, have a sense of place, and take pride in being Texans. If they lose our ties to the land, the price of progress is too high.
